I'm glad B will fail as it should.

To me, the principle least surprise mea=
ns that when o1 and o2 are not
null (regardless of their type) then

assert=
Equals(o1, o2)

should have the same result as

assertTrue(o1.equals(o2))

=
If that means that A fails then so be it.

Having said that, I am a bit sur=
prised that Integer.equals only
"likes" other Integers (and not Longs for e=
xample).  But we shouldn't
be fixing java.lang in junit.

--- In junit@yaho=
ogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>
> All,
> 
> Kent and I contin=
ue to try to fine-tune equality to produce the least
> surprise, and contin=
ue to wonder if well enough should have been left
> alone.  In 4.3, we intr=
oduced some run-time math magic to make up for
> the lack of type-expansion=
 once we had removed most of the primitive
> type assertEquals methods.  Th=
us, it became the case, somewhat
> accidentally, that this would pass:
> 
>=
 assertEquals(new Integer(1), new Long(1));  // A
> 
> However, it simultan=
eously became the case that this would also pass:
> 
> assertEquals(new Big=
Decimal("1.0"), new BigDecimal("1.1"));  // B
> 
> Line B should certainly =
fail.  The simplest thing to do is to remove
> our math magic, introduce as=
sertEquals(long, long), etc, and let
> numerical classes define their own e=
quality.  This means that line A
> will now fail, since that's how Integer.=
equals() is defined.  This is
> a small behavior change, but a "regression"=
 of sorts.
> 
> If anyone believes this is a damaging decision, please let =
me know.
> 
>    David Saff
>
